mn122:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
mn122:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
mn122:2.2: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the dwelling of Kāḷakhemaka the Sakyan for the day’s meditation.
mn122:2.3: Now at that time many resting places had been spread out at Kāḷakhemaka’s dwelling.

mn122:2.8: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda, together with many other mendicants, was making robes in Ghaṭa the Sakyan’s dwelling.
mn122:2.9: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ghaṭa’s dwelling, where he sat on the seat spread out
mn122:2.11: “Many resting places have been spread out at Kāḷakhemaka’s dwelling;
mn122:2.15: It’s currently the time for making robes.”
mn122:3.1: “Ānanda, a mendicant doesn’t shine who enjoys company and groups, who loves them and likes to enjoy them.
mn122:3.2: It’s simply not possible that such a mendicant will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
mn122:3.3: But you should expect that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group, will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is possible.
mn122:4.1: Indeed, Ānanda, it is not possible that a mendicant who enjoys company will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
mn122:4.2: But it is possible that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
mn122:5.1: Ānanda, I do not see even a single sight which, with its decay and perishing, would not give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in someone who has desire and lust for it.
mn122:6.1: But the Realized One woke up to this meditation, namely
mn122:6.2: to enter and remain in emptiness internally by not focusing on any signs.
mn122:6.3: Now, suppose that while the Realized One is practicing this meditation, monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, rulers and their ministers, monastics of other religions and their disciples go to visit him.
mn122:6.4: In that case, with a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, he invariably gives each of them a talk emphasizing the topic of dismissal.

mn122:7.2: ‘May I enter and remain in emptiness internally!’ So they should still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally.
mn122:7.3: And how does a mendicant still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally?

mn122:8.5: That’s how a mendicant stills, settles, unifies, and immerses their mind in samādhi internally.

mn122:11.1: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to walking, they walk, thinking:
mn122:11.2: ‘While I’m walking, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:11.4: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to standing, they stand, thinking:
mn122:11.5: ‘While I’m standing, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.6: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:11.7: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to sitting, they sit, thinking:
mn122:11.8: ‘While I’m sitting, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.9: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:11.10: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to lying down, they lie down, thinking:
mn122:11.11: ‘While I’m lying down, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
mn122:11.12: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:12.1: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to talking, they think:
mn122:12.2: ‘I will not engage in the kind of speech that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such speech doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Namely: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.’
mn122:12.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:12.4: ‘But I will take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.’
mn122:12.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:13.1: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to thinking, they think:
mn122:13.2: ‘I will not think the kind of thought that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such thoughts don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.’
mn122:13.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
mn122:13.4: ‘But I will think the kind of thought that is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. That is, thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.’
mn122:13.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.

mn122:18.1: These principles are entirely skillful, with skillful outcomes; they are noble, transcendent, and inaccessible to the Wicked One.
mn122:19.2: For what reason would a disciple value following the Teacher, even if sent away?”
mn122:19.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
mn122:20.1: “A disciple should not value following the Teacher for the sake of statements, songs, or discussions.
mn122:20.3: Because for a long time you have learned the teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
mn122:20.4: But a disciple should value following the Teacher, even if asked to go away, for the sake of talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
mn122:21.1: This being so, Ānanda, there is a peril for the teacher, a peril for the student, and a peril for a spiritual practitioner.
mn122:22.1: And how is there a peril for the teacher?
mn122:22.2: It’s when some teacher frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:22.3: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
mn122:22.4: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:22.5: This teacher is said to be imperiled by the teacher’s peril.
mn122:22.6: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
mn122:22.7: That’s how there is a peril for the teacher.
mn122:23.1: And how is there a peril for the student?
mn122:23.2: It’s when the student of a teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
mn122:23.3: frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:23.4: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
mn122:23.5: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:23.6: This student is said to be imperiled by the student’s peril.
mn122:23.7: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
mn122:23.8: That’s how there is a peril for the student.
mn122:24.1: And how is there a peril for a spiritual practitioner?
mn122:24.2: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
mn122:24.3: He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:24.4: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
mn122:24.5: When this happens, he doesn’t enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:24.6: But a disciple of this teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
mn122:24.7: frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn122:24.8: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
mn122:24.9: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
mn122:24.10: This spiritual practitioner is said to be imperiled by the spiritual practitioner’s peril.
mn122:24.11: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
mn122:24.12: That’s how there is a peril for the spiritual practitioner.
mn122:24.13: And in this context, Ānanda, as compared to the peril of the teacher or the student, the peril of the spiritual practitioner has more painful, bitter results, and even leads to the underworld.
mn122:25.1: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
mn122:25.2: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
mn122:25.3: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend?
mn122:25.4: It’s when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion:
mn122:25.5: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
mn122:25.6: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t pay attention or apply their minds to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
mn122:25.7: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend.
mn122:26.1: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy?
mn122:26.2: It’s when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion:
mn122:26.3: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
mn122:26.4: And their disciples want to listen. They pay attention and apply their minds to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
mn122:26.5: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy.
mn122:26.6: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
mn122:26.7: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
mn122:27.1: I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter with their damp, unfired pots.
mn122:27.2: I shall speak, correcting you again and again,
mn122:27.4: The core will stand the test.”
mn122:27.5: That is what the Buddha said.
mn122:27.6: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
